Q2c_grav_pull_moon.name: name
Q2c_grav_pull_moon.question: Have a look at the results for the gravitational pull from the Moon on 1 kg of mass on Earth. To which equation in the book does this result correspond? Type 1.11a for Equation (1.11a).

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect, please try again. The generation of the tide is described in Section 3.7.

Q2c_grav_pull_sun.name: name
Q2c_grav_pull_sun.question: Have a look at the results for the gravitational pull from the Sun on 1 kg of mass on Earth. To which equation in the book does this result correspond? Type 1.11a for Equation (1.11a).

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect, please try again. The generation of the tide is described in Section 3.7.

Q2c_diff_pull_moon.name: name
Q2c_diff_pull_moon.question: Have a look at the differential pull from the Moon for the near-side of the Earth. To which equation in the book should we compare this result? Type 1.11a for Equation (1.11a).

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect, please try again. The generation of the tide is described in Section 3.7.

Q2c_diff_pull_sun.name: name
Q2c_diff_pull_sun.question: Have a look at the differential pull from the Sun for the near-side of the Earth. To which equation in the book should we compare this result? Type 1.11a for Equation (1.11a).

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect, please try again. The generation of the tide is described in Section 3.7.

Q2c_diff_pull_reflect.name: name
Q2c_diff_pull_reflect.question: As you can see, the results for the near-side differential pull are slightly different than in the book. Compare the two computation methods and select the correct statements:

options.a: The values in this notebook are more accurate; in the book an approximation is used.
options.b: The values in the book are more accurate; in the notebook an approximation is used.
options.c: Using the computation procedure of the book, we would find exactly the same value (except for a minus sign) for the far-side of the Earth (point G) as for the near-side (point C).
options.d: Using the computation procedure of the notebook, we would find exactly the same value (except for a minus sign) for the far-side of the Earth (point G) as for the near-side (point C).

feedback.correct: Correct. The differential pull at C and G are approximately the same in magnitude.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Compare the computation in the notebook with the computation in the book (see the equation numbers that you entered in the two questions above). You can also extend the code in the notebook to compute the differential pull for G if you are in doubt about your answer. Is it the same as for C?

Q2c_moon_vs_sun.name: name
Q2c_moon_vs_sun.question: Now we can see that the differential pull is actually larger for the Moon than for the Sun. Can you explain why this is the case? This is because:

options.a: The mass of the Sun is much larger than that of the Moon.
options.b: The distance to the Moon is much smaller than to the Sun.
options.c: The period of the orbit is an order of magnitude larger for the Earth-Sun system.
options.d: The Moon orbits the Earth, while the Earth orbits the Sun.

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Hint: look at the equations for the near-side differential pull in the book. What are these dependent on?

Q2c_angle_moon_0.name: name
Q2c_angle_moon_0.question: Select New moon (angle_moon = 0) to create the figure. Which of the below statements is/are true?

options.a: The Moon and the Sun are found on the same side of the Earth.
options.b: The Moon and the Sun are found on opposite sides of the Earth.
options.c: The Moon is at a right angle with respect to the Sun when viewed from Earth.
options.d: The Moon has travelled about a quarter of the way around Earth since full moon.

feedback.correct: Correct. See also Figure 3.21 in the book.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Set the angles in the notebook figure and compare with Figure 3.21 in the book.
